title: Aluminium heated bed plate for Ultimaker

description.text:
This is a upgraded Aluminium build plate for the Ultimaker 3d printer. This plate is 6mm thick, with a 2mm cut out space for a reprap PCB HBP. Files included:
solidworks drawing
solidworks part
solidworks drawing .pdf
.stl NOTE
You will require a mill to manufacture this, i'm currently waiting for mine to be made at the uni's CNC mill. - will post a update when complete!

to build this simply order a 6mm thick aluminum plate (250 x 250mm is what i got) and mill out the design on a standard or CNC mill.
as it goes for fixing the PCB to the slot im hoping for a tight fit and i shall possibly use some kapton or ceramic tape if needed. if this is a no-go i have a few other solutions 1) print out some "swivel brackets" (like the ones on picture frames)
2) use 10mm plate and drill and tap the 4 holes on the plate inline with the PCB corner holes and use screws ill post a update soon with the finish product and some photo's and how i attached the PCB plate.

comments.text: Just a thought: you might want to dig a small deeper hole where the HBP's connectors and leds are located.

title: Rope Friction Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a parametric script for generating a simple board with regularly spaced holes. I'm using it instead of knots for polypropylene rope that doesn't knot well.
The geometry is fundamentally 2D so this could be done with a laser cutter or even a drill.

The script lets you set the number of holes, the board thickness, the hole radius, and the amount of spacing between holes. 
Print, clean, thread rope.
Don't use for anything that might kill you if things go wrong.

description.text:
My wife has a classic Fuji Club Fuji road bike but at this time of year in New England fenders help keep the water off the rider.  Unfortunately all the fender sets out there today are V-brake setups instead of the classic style and mounting directly to the caliper mount doesn't provide enough clearance for the fender.
She asked me to whip up these adapters so she could easily mount the fenders.

1) Print (On my ToM 0.35 mm layer height 25% infill)
2) Mount on bike and to fender
3) Enjoy!

Filament reels have a nasty tendency to spontaneously unroll their contents, resulting in kinked, tangled and broken filament.  After a number of 'air prints' I decided to design a tensioner device for my Makerbot Replicator 1 Dual.  The principle is simple - apply a steady frictional force to the face of the reel, thereby preventing it from unrolling.  
The OpenSCAD code allows customisation of the dimensions, adjustment of the number of springs (thereby varying the reel friction) and either a Left- or Right-handed tensioner.   The supplied dimensions suit the original reel spindles on the Replicator 1 Dual.

Printed on a Makerbot Replicator 1 Dual at 90/150 mm/s, 0.2 mm layer thickness and 2 shells, with 10% infill, raft and supports.  
You will need to remove the supports underneath the leaf springs prior to use - just use a pair of pliers.

title: shapeoko / megaoko far Y motor wire clip

description.text:
I lost the default cable route for the far y motor when I closed the gap between the x rails, so I decided to route the wire in the second top rail. To keep it in place I created this clip to route it, attaches with a standard t-nut. I replaced the smaller spacer on the Gantry with 20mm spacers and joined the two rails with 4 of these joiners printed 4x in height.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:74301
I'm getting way less flex now.

Simple combination spanner/box wrench for ER11 collet spindles.
Open spanner is for the spindle shank and is 13mm flat to flat.
Box Wrench is for the collet ring and is 17.25mm flat to flat.
I printed these from ABS with a LH of .3mm, Infill of 50% and 4 perimeter passes. Plenty strong for tightening collets and not crushing anything.

You have (a friend with) a Batman fixation? You feel unsafe on your city’s streets? Don’t you worry, with this miniature Batsignal the dark knight will show up whenever you need him!
Images of the actual working thing will be added shortly as I forgot to take any and gave it away for Christmas.

Print all the parts, use superglue and screws (1m5; 2m3) to connect them in the right order (I’ll trust you on this one). Then disassemble a flashlight and glue the lamp in place. If you use an LED flashlight you want to cover it with aluminum foil in which you have punched a hole in the middle. This will enable your lamp to give a sharp and clean projection. To finish it, you might want to line the interior of the lamp with aluminum foil to make it brighter? (As I did this right away, I can’t tell you what purpose it serves, feel free to skip this step).
Glue the batteries into its dedicated spot in the base. That’s it!
-try to call batman, if he does not show up in 20 minutes you might want to get a brighter light….

description.text: uCurrent - elektronik.si enclosure
A rabbit, a camel, and a man's face walked into a bar. Humphrey emerged. I added the pedestal to honor them/him/it.
My 16 yr old son made this object. I've printed it many times. This version (pictured) is in the PLA green -- and it sparkles.

THE DESIGN HAS BEEN UPDATED. PLEASE SEE THING 1098809. This is a model of mechanism 329 from http://507movements.com/
Designed in MOI. Made on a Robox from Robox ABS.
As you can easily see the surface finish is poor. This in NOT a reflection on the engineering or precision of the Robox, merely the less-than-fully-developed state of the software.
So, the model doesn't look as nice as it should, but works fine, as your can see for yourself in the video: http://youtu.be/dvHLU3Owg_Y
As you can see in the video there is a certain amount for flexing going on reflecting the limits of accuracy of the FDM process - and the clearances that I provided. Making in PLA may require more extensive post print finishing.
The screw holes are sized for 3mm screws. I used button head cap screws. OAL of 8mm for retention of the smaller gear and the connecting rod, 10mm OAL elsewhere.
No special instructions other than to check the part orientation prior to printing.

After seeing some kids playing with a little air plane powered by compressed air from a soda bottle, I decided to see if I could make a laser cuttable version of such a motor. This is not a very powerful or efficient motor, but it is a fully working printable ("cuttable"?) air vane motor. My next goal will be to make a full printable bottle-powered park-flyer. A video of the motor in action: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=reaB0R9ALHs More on air vane motors:
http://www.hydraulicspneumatics.com/200/TechZone/FluidPowerAcces/Article/True/6422/TechZone-FluidPowerAcces Matt made a version for 3D printers. You can find it here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:620

The laser cutter ponoko used to produce this left small "pixelated" indentations along all curves (see image). No big deal, except the vanes need to slide unimpeded along the inner ring, so it had to be sanded and polished manually for the motor to work.
The screw holes are superflous as the acrylic does not really seal well by just screwing the three layers together. I had to glue them with generous amount of Faller Expert Plastic Cement anyway.
I also sanded the sides of the rotor slightly to decrease friction.
For propellant I used a can of common Dust Off.

comments.text: Hi all, I had a shot at making this. I cut a gasket type thing out of acetate too to the same pattern as the middle ring, to increase the seperation therein to give some space for the rotor to move. That's the part that you see in my photo above. Otherwise the thing looks just like everyone elses - I got a heck of a lot of leakage from the central hole, where the rotor pivots around a bolt. Any nifty solutions for that?

comments.author: daewootech

comments.text: So i ended up spending a good portion of the day fiddling with this :-D I first modified the design a bit by spiraling the turbine to allow more airflow, then i modified the exhaust ports to scale larger in 20% increments until the last one is 200% larger than the first. Then i changed the scale of the turbine, it was originaly 1.41 inches but i saw in the plans it would fit snug at 1.45 so i scaled it up larger for a better fit. then assembled it and realized it didnt spin to well, the material was all the same size which means the turbine would rub against thewalls, so i made two spacers the same thickness as the washers i had and put washers on either side of the turbine after that i drilled out all the holes to fit the #6 screws that i had. screwed it together with 6 brass #6 screws and the middle with the same. It works pretty awesome at arond 20-50 psi with the air compressor, but it started to spin so fast that it was vibrating, i thought where the screw touched the turbine, so i recreated the turbine with a larger center hole (~.31in) and stuck a bearing i had laying around.  :-D

description.text:
This is the Hovership MHQ2 but cut and repaird with net fab, so now you can print this with a printer as small as a printer bot simple!! Hope this is helped! This will be 25 hours of printing if you use the following settings: 0.1 layer height, 1.0 shell 100% infill and print speed at 40mm/s. Here is a link to original project: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:511668 From Hovership: The redesigned 3D printed MHQ2 folding mini quadcopter frame has arrived! Building on the success of the original MHQ frame, we have improved the functionality, durability and stability of this frame. The MHQ2 uses the same arms and hardware from the MHQ with the addition of 4x more 18mm screws and 4x locknuts. The use of 6" props is possible with the new XL arms. Flight compilation video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vrj7iZE8P1M Printed kits available at: http://shop.hovership.com/hovership-mhq2/
Hardware kits available: http://shop.hovership.com/mhq2-hardware-kit/
Power system: http://shop.hovership.com/power-systems/
Propellers: http://shop.hovership.com/propellers/ KEY NEW FEATURES: Redesigned base with greatly reduced torsion for better flight stability.
Camera and battery have a lower center of gravity. Both now mount down on the flight control deck.
Hardtail mounting: you can skip the clean layer and mount the top plate directly to the base.
Wider landing gear and slots on the underside of the baseplate for mounting the battery if preferred.
Improved landing gear thickness and durability.
Mounting holes for SMA extension cables.
Integrated GoPro and Mobius mount. Reinforced structure reduces damage in a crash and elevates the GoPro for the use of a USB live-out FPV cable.
Support for M3 "bobbin" style vibration dampeners.
Now with 35mm spacers to support flight controllers with straight header pins.
ASSEMBLY INSTRUCTIONS: Available Online at: http://www.hovership.com/guides RECOMMENDED CONFIGURATIONS Full Component List (BOM): http://www.hovership.com/guides/mhq2-build-components-list/ Beginner pilots and lightweight FPV with a Mobius or smaller camera: 1804-2204 size 2300kv motors, 3-cell (3s) 1300-1800mAh lipo battery and 5? propellers Beginner to intermediate pilots and FPV with a GoPro or similar action camera: 2204 size 2300kv motors, 3-cell (3s) 1300mAh lipo battery and 6? propellers Intermediate to advanced pilots with GoPro or smaller camera: 2204 1960kv motors, 4-cell (4s) 1300mAh lipo battery and 5-6? propellers. UPDATES 12.01.2014 - Added V2 of rugged arm. Added short version of clean-lower: this is 6mm shorter and should fit better on 200x200mm print beds (placed diagonally).

You will need some Krazy glue to glue the pieces together. and then put some eletrical tape on the glued pieces to make it stronger. From Hovership: Print Settings
=== 200x200mm minimum print bed is required. The largest part should fit when rotated 45 degrees and printed diagonally on the bed.
Arms and landing gear: 75% infill or more, 2-3 walls
Plates: 40% Infill, 2-3 walls
Required Hardware
==== Motors:
-- 16x 6mm M2 or M3 bolts - depending on which motors you use
Arms: 4x 18mm M3 bolts
4x 20mm M3 bolts
8x M3 nylon washers
8x M3 thin metal washers
8x M3 lock nuts
Base 4x 18mm M3 bolts
4x M3 lock nuts
Landing gear: 4x 18mm M3 bolts
4x M3 lock nuts
Standoffs (to separate the upper decks): The two deck plates that are separated with these standoffs have holes for 8 but I found that 6 was enough, 3 in opposing corners.
35mm M3 female threaded spacers
12x 5mm M3 bolts
Vibration dampeners: ATG small grey (7mm hole mounting): http://www.goodluckbuy.com/4-pcs-atg-anti-vibration-sphere-av-ball-high-elastic-rubber-ball-dual-head-anti-vibration-for-ptz-small.html or http://www.aliexpress.com/item/ATG-AV-Ball-High-Elastic-Rubber-Ball-Dual-head-Anti-vibration-for-PTZ-Small-Grey-color/1023411887.html
Or any 4x M3 "bobbin" style vibration dampener: http://shop.hovership.com/m3-rubber-vibration-bobbins/

I like the case redpeppr made, but I wanted to have the Raspberry logo on it. So I adapted it to make it multicolor.
It turned out to be quite nice. I had to transport my printer recently, so my Z-endstop is a little bit too high. Maybe I make a new one with better settings.

Make sure the models are centered correctly before slicing. The four little dots make sure that both models are the same size.
  • Print the infill first at 0.5 mm first layer height with your desired color, I used red.
  • Remove the four little dots and switch your filament to the second color, I used white. Try not to home the printer to make sure everything aligns.
  • Print the cutout at 0.45 mm first layer height to improve adhesion. Slicer thinks it needs to bridge the other parts so you need to change this setting for a better result.
  • Carefully remove the part as the logo might come of.
  • Print one of the bottom parts from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:30572 or use the one with screw holes (M3).

comments.text: Just a thought, what if you slice each one individually, then combine the gcodes with a pause? With Sailfish, very easily done? Heated pause would let you change the filament easily.  Very nice work and concept!!!!!

Maybe I'll come up with an idea to fix these problems. But I think combining g-codes is a lot of work when you can do it this way.

description.text: A Lithophane medallion I made as a gag gift for a coworker. Looks great as a window hang or backlit.

Viedma Glacier in Argentina constructed using 1 arcsecond resolution SRTM data from the Space Shuttle (about 2.4 million polygons). This model was created using a new and, as yet, unreleased version of SRTM2STL. The source code for creating files at 3 arcsecond resolution is available up on github under the GNU license. Go to github and search for SRTM2STL.

You may want to print this to be relatively small. I get warping using PLA and it gets bad when I try to print Raised Relief Maps that are big. I have had 'some' success with big maps. If you have a way to control warping you may also have better luck with big maps.

The previous design was meant to allow for experimentation in placement and the like.
This thing improves on the original design by integrating the shelf clip into the motor holding rectangle itself.  The shelf clip is also shifted to be at the top of the side of the rectangle, rather than at the top.  This gives a little bit more stable support when the motor is spinning.

1) Grab your Nema 17 motor
2) Put one or two of these sleeves on it
3) Slide the mount onto a 'shelf'.
-- Default configuration is 6.5mm for the shelf thickness --
4) Rejoice! This one could probably use a fastener of some sort. You could go with driving a screw through it, and locking to the shelf. Or you could simply glue the clip to the shelf. Using two clips makes things even more stable. There is room to fit three if you want total coverage. You can configure your own size fairly easily in the OpenScad file.

As it happens, a Dremel or similar rotary tool can be used to perform a "blind rivet" using friction welding techniques: 3D printed rivets fused into a 3D printed surface.
More on this technique as I begin to share projects I created that make use of blind rivets.

After experimentation, I have determined that it is better to print these flat with the long thread runs on the horizontal plane. And that printing 1/2 to 3/4s of the rivet produces a part that can still spin and fuse pretty much the same way that an entire rivet works. 
Also, printing these from the base of the rivet up to the mandrel tends to produce rivets that break too easily on the layer, so while it is tempting to bring a whole army of them on their bases, I recommend flat instead, but perhaps nine or twelve of these at a time.
Included in this project are two test parts -- a "base" and a "pancake" layer. You can line up the hole through the pancake with the depression in the base to teach yourself the gentle touch required to touch the spinning rivet to the base such that the "melt zone" is shared equally by both base of blind rivet and surface of base. At that point, stop the rotary tool, holding the rivet in place until it cools. It can help to use something to press against the rotary head so that it spins down more quickly. The release the mandrel from the rotary tool and you have a nice blind rivet!

title: Dualstrusion Numbered Pawns for roleplaying games

description.text:
A remix of my numbered pawns, but for a dualstrusion printer. This makes them much easier to read, and actually easier to print too, no worry about supports, and the resulting pawns are sturdier. Plus I got to use a much prettier font (Aniron).  
The idea of these is is you can use them to represent the various gnolls and orcs and brigands and whatever other enemies your doughty warriors go up against. Because ten figurines all showing a goblin may be more apt, but they're not very useful when initiative says it's time for Goblin #5 to act, and you're wondering, which one is #5 because they all look the same.
Should be a quick and easy print without any supports or raft required.

author: HunterGreen

description.text: I wanted to get some feet, but decided I would try out a set of hardware to mount my PrintrBro to a few pieces of MDF,  Even though my prints were sticking good, there was a bit of warping, so these are probably not ideal for use as feet on their own.  With that being said, once screwed in to the fiber board, this set up is pretty stout.  Now I should be ready for my 600mm x axis extension (ok, maybe just 200-300mm).

Vitamins:
Two pieces of 1/2# MDF, cut 1' x 1'
4-6 #8 Washers
4-6 3/4" wood screws
Gorilla Glue (If you are glueing the link between the two rear pieces) Tools:
Hex Alan wrench for the Printrbot M3 Screws
Some liquid nails and a caulk gun Steps:
1) Print the parts, everything should fit (one at a time) on the 1405 stock 100 x 100 x 100 bed. I used PLA and Slic3r. Also note, there isn't a seperate STL for the right front foot, just import the left front STL and then use a mirror function in Repetier to to get the opposite parity.
2) Add the feet one at a time. Take off the existing M3 screw on the Printrbot for each. Add the foot and then screw in the same M3 screw (each existing screw has enough space to reach the nut without using a longer M3 screw).
2A) If you want to use the link, it goes between the two rear feet. Bond with super glue but make sure there is a good fit between both rear corners.
3) Cut the MDF if needed. Adhrere two pieces together using liquid nails. Make sure they are square and then press them together until they are bonded (I was impatient and only waited about an hour, but waiting longer is probably advised.
4) Lay down your bot and then use wood screws and washers to secure the feet to the MDF. I only used 4, but you can double up on the front feet if you feel like it. If you screw up the MDF, no sweat. A 2' x 4' sheet costs about $9.

comments.text: I didn't make a separate file for that.  The right front and left front feet are mirror images, so you just need to import the STL for the left into Repetier and then use the mirror function to get layout that works for the other side.

comments.text: What material and infill did you use?
comments.author: Khross

comments.text: MMM... I used ABS but PLA would work as well.  ABS has the advantage of melting with acetone so to really smooth it out, you can wipe it down with an acetone soaked rag.  Infill, I don't fully remember but probably 33% which is common for me.  Perhaps lower.  The critical thin is to rotate so it prints on it's side.  Much like bamboo, the strands give it the strength.  If you print it on its back, the bands will be circular creating a weakness to the pressure point extension.  Make sense?  You may want to make the outer shell 4 or 5 layers thick as well.  Just to add some bulk.

comments.text: Point of interest.. Be sure to rotate this and print it on its side for strength.  Similar to bamboo or rattan, the strength comes from the grain going lengthwise.  If you print it with the cylindrical surface up, it will be weak and break.  If your program doesn't allow you to rotate, use Autodesk Meshmixer (free app) or hollar at me and I'll rotate it for you.

title: Easy Y axis cable chain mount for Prusa i3
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I love the idea of cable chain to keep everything tidy. I printed out http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:57533 and found that the piece that holds one end of the y axis cable chain on the frame of the i3 printer requires major disassembly of the Y axis. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WjeptaI2T8E This part does the same job with a much easier install, less plastic, and no overhangs. I design stuff all the time. follow me @ http://marginallyclever.com
print

Lay flat.  You may need to flip it on one axis - depends on which side you want to install.  
Install

locate the M10 threaded shaft on which you want to install.  loosen the bolt on the side of the frame where you want to install.  Slide this piece between the frame and the nut.  if there is also a washer, keep the washer between this piece and the nut.  Attach the cable chain.

remixed_from.author: biomushroom
remixed_from.title: J-Head Bracket with Servo mount for Auto Bed Leveling - Prusa i3

remixed_from.author: indieflow
remixed_from.title: Prusa i3 Direct Drive Bowden Extruder

title: j-head bracket with servo mount 3mm and 1/4th inch coupling

description.text:
I liked Biomushroom's j-head design with bracket, so i re-worked it with a 3mm filament hole and adjusted the pnumatic coupling hole to work with a 1/4th inch coupling. I used indieflow's scad files to create the base model, and i attached biomuchroom's mount. i removed the supports (the ones biomushroom made were nice and worked well, but i feel safer using supports made by a slicing program) and made them a little bit simplier. I also added a modified version of the main part of indieflow's direct drive extruder. This one is redesigned for 3mm filament and the larger coupling. I haven't yet tested it with the mk7 drive gear, the filament hole might need to get adjusted. I printed one out and it worked OK, however i've been making a few more modifications to get everything working right. I'm tracking my changes on github:
https://github.com/monofuel/Prusa3
and i'll keep the latest mono_bracket.scad up-to-date. This one currently does not have the servo-mount. changes i've made for mono_bracket:
i had issues fitting my 3m cap screws and my 3m philips scrws into the holes of the j-head clamp, so i increased their size a little bit. I also had issues with my screws threading into the clamp. I could have reamed the holes, but i decided to make them bigger on the model. i modified the size of all holes ment for 3m screws to be 3m. The origional design used slightly smaller holes for self-tapping screws (with the exception of the two holes on the top) however I went with using a tap and die kit to thread each hole. the 3/8ths with 24 pitch pneumatic fitting hole was hard to thread and fit rather poorly, so i made the hole deeper. It's still 1mm short of fully screwing the coupling in with the latest version, but to get the additional inch would either mean leaving no plastic between the coupling and the j-head, or increasing the height of the bracket. I adjusted the filament hole to 3.4mm. i tried 3.2mm, but it ended up as a rather tight fit for filament. I haven't made any modifications to the scale of each part, as they all fit together correctly on my printer. Any changes i've made have comments on github.

comments.text: I should have remembered to measure twice and cut once, my couplings are actually 3/8th with threading pitch 24. I'll get new ones modeled and uploaded. I've printed one so far, and it fits my servo nicely!
comments.author: monofuel

comments.text:
Great work.
I'm going to release the dual j-head bracket and the new carriage, as part of my new Prusa P3Di3 (P3D stands for Pixel3Design).
Just a thing, put the licence in Non Commercial please.

author: monofuel

description.text: This parametric brick takes the popular work of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5699 a couple steps further, adding easy Customizer support and support for generating wings, smooth-topped tiles, DUPLO-style bricks, sloped bricks, Technic-style holes, and more. Depending on the resolution of your printer, you may not be able to print pieces that fit exactly with standard LEGO blocks. If you do print any of these bricks, I'd be interested to know whether they fits together with other bricks, especially if you have an SLS or SLA printer. These blocks are not strictly identical to LEGO bricks, but they should be compatible in most every way. 2016/02/14: Updated with support for double-female-sided bricks: no studs on top or bottom. 2015/01/12: Updated with support for double-sided bricks: studs on the top and bottom. 2015/01/11: Updated with support for baseplates, roadways, and better error detection. 2015/01/07: Updated with support for curved bricks. 2015/01/07: Updated with support for sloped bricks. 2015/01/06: Updated with support for DUPLO-style bricks. 2015/01/03: Updated with support for including horizontal holes to fit rods and axles, as seen in the Technic line of LEGO bricks. 2014/12/31: Updated with support for generating wings. 2014/12/30: Updated with support for hollow studs. 2014/12/30: Updated with perfect centering of knobs, posts, pins, axle holes, and reinforcements. 2014/12/30: Updated to print tiles upside-down to remove the need for reinforcement. 2014/12/30: Updated with newly accurate measurements. 2014/12/30: Updated to use a specific post wall diameter instead of an estimate based on the knob diameter. LEGO®, the LEGO® logo, the Brick, DUPLO®, and MINDSTORMS® are trademarks of the LEGO® Group.

The replacement wall holder for the old Curver recycle bin.  
OpenSCAD sources included.

Feeding filament from the drawer underneath may cause filament feed issues which could affect print completion and quality. This is a simple alternative filament feed system you can print on almost any 3D printer and is not greatly more than a side mounted spool holder (designed for the recommended 900gm MakerBot PLA spools).   
The concept is that the lengthy feed path through Teflon tube from the base of the Z18 combined with the 'uphill feed path can cause excessive resistance so not enough filament is always available quick enough on demand from the machine. In addition, the filament on some spools can be slightly stuck to underlying/adjacent filament which means extra tension is required to pull it away. All of these issues could cause under extrusion and this spool holder is aimed at reducing these factors to achieve better print reliability and quality. .   
There is only one print to make this change. It includes two pieces... a spool holder and a threaded bolt to secure it to the side of your Z18 with the lid removed. Please read the instructions carefully and refer closely to the images to see the correct fitment (... but it's not exactly rocket science)   
STL Files/Versions: The standard .stl is designed for use with standard MakerBot spools. A 'Wide' and 'X-Wide' version has been added that will take alternative spools up to 60mm and 80mm wide respectively. This is still a screw on fitting (80mm version should accept 1Kg MakerBot spools. Not tested but should be okay).  
Add-on Accessory: Also added is a 'Filament Guide'. This is useful when running a new very full MakerBot spool as the filament can run over the top and into the inside of the spool holder. When placed along the side of the Z18 in between the spool and filament entry into the cabinet, this little attachment stops the filament from being able to unwind high enough to get over the side of the spool and drop down the side of the spool holder. Very small but useful addition...

Print with Raft but no support. Use 4+ shells and at least 30% fill to ensure adequate strength. After printing and removing the raft check the thread on the bolt is clean as possible then it should thread into the threaded part of the spool holder with minimal effort. This will tighten against the inside panel of the Z18.   
Install mid way across the right side of the Z18 with the lid removed (not required). Disconnect the side feed tube from the Y connector and join with the filament guide tube going to the extruder. They will slide together okay with a small amount of force.   
Please refer to the images for additional understanding. Hopefully this helps your Z18 feed filament better.

This is my second attempt at understanding the operations in OpenSCAD.
I made a model of a 4" square electrical box with a raised plaster ring in AutoCAD and then exported to an STL. I couldn't get emmett's heart gears file to work, so I basically destroyed the original cubeGears3 code http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10483 until it didn't work either. I rebuilt it enough to get the result I was looking for. I made both the Gear1 and Gear2 module accept x and z rotation inputs (1 or 2), and then added some rotation code inside those modules, the twogears module, and the assembly module to make them behave for a non cube object. I added an object module that loads a custom stl file and orients it for gear mashup. I am still not clear on the way the relationship between the overall model, the center and pins is determined. I cheated and just tweaked the center cube until it looked like I wanted, and then I measured the necessary pin length and used the Pins library to make one. I have not posted this revised code, because I don't really feel that it is any way an improvement over the original. I may post it if requested, or if I can work some of the remaining bugs out.
The center stl has emmett's original slits, but I reoriented it in such a way to make them not work as originally intended. It is OK, because it cleans up easily, and I made the center pins captured anyway.

This is a large model.  It measures 4"x4"x2-7/8" when assembled.  It is a life sized model.
Gear1-1-1, Gear1-2-1, Gear2-1-1, Gear2-2-1 require support material under the protruding plaster ring part of the box.  I had trouble getting Skienforge to slice this with support just under these overhangs, so I sliced it with Makerware.  It places support material under the entire part, even though the gear portions will print without it.  Cleanup is somewhat difficult, because you have to be careful to not harm the teeth.
Gear1-1-2, Gear1-2-2, Gear2-1-2, Gear2-2-2, Center, and Pin can be printed supportless.  You will need 8 pins to assemble the model.
I printed this in silver PLA with .25 layers, bed temp 60, extruder 220, 2 shells, 5% infill, 3 bottom layers, and 4 top layers.

title: Pot / Tub Clips... Quick and easy clips for part used pot/tubs in the fridge
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Unless you always finish a pot / tub whenever you open it chances are you've ended up having to find a way to temporarily reseal it... or leave the original lid on and it ends up curling at the edges which effectively opens it up.  
If you don't like leaving these tubs / pots open the common 'fixes' are a rubber band or aluminium foil neither of which are ideal as one flicks off easily and doesn't seal that well and the other is wasteful and not always easy to remove again.   
Because there is a variety of shapes/sizes/curvatures of these pots / tubs it took a bit of trial and error to work out this system which will accommodate and work effectively on almost all of them.  
The result is these clips which provide an effective solution that should fit most regular size pots / tubs of everything from sour cream to yogurt etc. However, a word of caution, while these work well in my country (New Zealand) you may need to scale the Z size if packaging dimensions are different in your country.   
If you like this take time to check out my other designs!
Print using raft / 3 or 4 shells and 30 - 40% infill to make them robust enough to last.

comments.text: I used to find half used pots of things (like sour cream) in the fridge with the top layer getting all dried out because the foil/plastic lid was curling up leaving it 'open'. This resolved it and since then we've found it can also be used on a lot of containers with a tear seal on the top cover. Its just 'tidy' and overcomes a small annoyance I had....it's been a popular download here on Thingiverse so it seems plenty of people see value in them. We have half a dozen at home with at least 3 or 4 in use most of the time for various things.

Over time through frequent removal and installation of the MakerBot Mini build Plate it may become loose and move up and down at the front. Out of the box, when everything is new and firm, this isn't an issue however as the built plate is not supported underneath whatsoever, when the brackets holding it start to wear the build plate can start moving around. This can affect print quality and/or cause Smart Extruder issues. The Mini Stablizer Plate can be printed on a Mini and simply drops in place before installing the build plate as per usual. It effectively adds solid support underneath the build plate so it can't drop down. Movement is almost eliminated. The Build Plate Stabilizer prints upside down so make sure you invert it when you install it. This makes the Stabilizer lock against the existing brackets to form a solid and stable base for the Mini build plate to sit on. Please Note:
(1) The Stabilizer Plate was developed with prints from a Replicator 2. Please check it does not affect the original build plate height or position as that could affect the Mini's positioning and/or first layers. This is intended to support the original build plate and make it more solid not reposition it or alter the level of the plate. Please check when installing it and watch the start of the first print closely. To achieve the desired result for your Mini you may need to print using slightly scaled Z height (the development print functions perfectly but not every machine will print the same as this was on a Replicator 2) (2) Nothing directly to do with this Build Plate Support, as it should not affect the standard Build Plate level, use the Z-Offset feature in MakerBot Desktop to increase the start clearance when first installing this plate. This provides a safety margin just in case. Having said that, even without the support plate fitted I have been adding 0.24mm to ensure adequate clearance so extrusion starts well... which helps avoid extruder issues.

Print with raft (standard on a Mini) with 4 shells and 25% or more infill to ensure the plate is solid and will adequately support the original build plate. The Stabilizer Plate prints upside down so invert to install. This makes it lock against the original brackets to provide a solid base platform for the Mini build plate and will effectively eliminate almost all up/down movement cue to wear. The Stabilizer Plate simply drops into place in a matter of seconds. No attachment required and the original build plate will slip in/out as usual on top of it but will be better supported almost to the front of the build plate as a result. Please Note:
(1) The Stabilizer Plate was developed with prints from a Replicator 2. Please check it does not affect the original build plate height or position as that could affect the Mini's positioning and/or first layers. This is intended to support the original build plate and make it more solid not reposition it or alter the level of the plate. Please check when installing it and watch the start of the first print closely. To achieve the desired result for your Mini you may need to print using slightly scaled Z height (the development print functions perfectly but not every machine will print the same as this was on a Replicator 2) (2) Nothing directly to do with this Build Plate Support, as it should not affect the standard Build Plate level, use the Z-Offset feature in MakerBot Desktop to increase the start clearance when first installing this plate. This provides a safety margin just in case. Having said that, even without the support plate fitted I have been adding 0.24mm to ensure adequate clearance so extrusion starts well... which helps avoid extruder issues.

comments.text: First off, great design. We tried unsuccessfully to print without a raft, until I found your support plate. Now we are printing without a raft and getting great first layer adhesion. This has seriously improved the performance of our machine, if you own a MakerBot Replicator Mini, you need to print this plate off and install it. No more removing rafts!
comments.author: billioncash

comments.text: Lengthy reply sent direct... warping is not a file issue it is a machine issue and exactly what this stabilizer plate is intended to address. If a build plate becomes loose print quality will be affected. The warping/curling is caused when the extruder runs towards the edges of the build plate and effectively pushes the print down as the extruded PLA hardens almost instantly underneath it. The result is pressure at the edges of the build plate so it moves down, then springs back and that action can cause the print to break away, particularly as the extruder does it's next pass and hits/grinds across the layer.

description.text: Inspired by the AA Glasses, I decided to make my own.  After a few iterations (some lasted upwards of 3 months, even with the abuse of a very rambunctious 2 year old).  This is my final design.  Hope somebody else will get good use of them too!

The only post processing is a little work with a heat gun to match the shape of the lenses and to make the ear portion a little more comfortable/fit more snugly. I used 2 pieces of 1/16" Stainless Tig rod for the hinges, but a piece of 1.75mm filament is what I designed them for. To Make the hinges permanent do the following:
  • Measure and cut your hinge filament piece leaving about 1/8" on either side hanging out.
  • Use a heat gun or torch to heat up a flat bladed knife.
  • Once the knife is hot enough to melt the plastic, gently use the side of the blade to smash both ends of the filament, creating a filament rivet.
  • Enjoy your new riveted hinges!

This is equipment for small-scale hydroponic culture.

You can use this in 4 ways;
  • Reusing an empty can (half-cut).
  • Printing a float and a cup.
  • Reusing an empty can and using LED as a light source.
  • Printing all the parts and using LED as a light source.
    • Additionally, you can choose AA battery or USB bus power for the LED power source. Although this is designed to be put in a living/dining room, you can put one anyware you want.
    Putting something green is a good practice to make your place more comfortable ;)

• Print mechanical parts with your 3D printer.
    • Choose required parts set depending on your usage.
  • Make an electrical circuit according to the diagram.
    • Electrical circuit diagram is available at https://github.com/Lunran/FourwayHydroponicSystem.
    • Instruction is available at http://lunran.sakura.ne.jp/wordpress/en/2015/01/04/%E6%A4%8D%E7%89%A9%E5%B7%A5%E5%A0%B4%E3%82%92%E4%BD%9C%E3%82%8B%E3%80%80%EF%BD%9E%E9%9B%BB%E5%AD%90%E5%9B%9E%E8%B7%AF%EF%BD%9E/
  • Compile and load the program in "Program" directory to your Trinket (Arduino).
    • Program is available at https://github.com/Lunran/FourwayHydroponicSystem
    • Instruction is available at http://lunran.sakura.ne.jp/wordpress/en/2015/01/11/%E6%A4%8D%E7%89%A9%E5%B7%A5%E5%A0%B4%E3%82%92%E4%BD%9C%E3%82%8B%E3%80%80%EF%BD%9E%E3%83%97%E3%83%AD%E3%82%B0%E3%83%A9%E3%83%A0%EF%BD%9E/
  • Put all the mechanical parts and electornic circuit together.
    • Instruction is available at http://lunran.sakura.ne.jp/wordpress/en/2015/01/12/%E6%A4%8D%E7%89%A9%E5%B7%A5%E5%A0%B4%E3%82%92%E4%BD%9C%E3%82%8B%E3%80%80%EF%BD%9E%E7%B5%84%E3%81%BF%E7%AB%8B%E3%81%A6%EF%BD%9E/
  • Ta-dah!

title: LG Roboking Replacement Brush (L and R)

description.text:
This is my first attempt at a useful 3D item!   
We recently bought an LG Roboking robotic vacuum - which is awesome BTW - but the right brush broke off.  The design is such that the left and right are slightly different. As luck would have it, I only have a left replacement spare. While waiting for LG support to send me a new one under warranty, I knocked one up just to see if I could do it.  A few goes later and a little fishing wire and viola! Not exactly the same but it seems to do the job.  
Happy to take comments on the design.   
Note 1: It does need to be scaled to fit - not sure what I have done wrong with the file. The diameter of the main circle should be 24mm (excluding the protruding brush parts).  
Note 2: I updated the file recently with a simpler design that is a little closer to the original.  The first attempt was too thick and fell off when the Roboking started its daily chore!

This replacement brush was modelled on the original. Note that the left and right brushes are directional and have a different centre - the left uses a hexagon and the right an octagon. The original is also more flexible being made of rubber around a metal axel. I have used ABS but I suspect PLA might be a little more durable in this case. I'll see how it goes. The design may need to change! Files:
LG Roboking Right/Left Brush v1.stl - original file for right/left brush
LG Roboking Right/Left Brush v1 Raised Tubes.stl -same file as above with tubes raised to allow access through them
LG Roboking Right Brush v1.jas - Cheetah3D source file
LG Roboking Left Brush v1.jas - Cheetah3D source file To print the main brush:
Be sure to scale so that the main circle is 24mm. In my UP! software, I needed to scale the file by 0.394. To create the brush once printed: Once scaled and printed, then simply use fishing line as the brush. On the design with the raised tubes, you can thread a length of fishing line in loops through each tube. Put as many as you can fit into the three tubes. Be sure to loop the fishing line and try to keep the right direction and similar sized loops. When complete, use some glue or acetone to fix and then simply cut each loop to leave the maximum amount of line. Be sure to cut so that the loops are in the direction of each tube. See pictures for reference. On the v1 design with embedded tubes, you will need to cut lengths of fishing line and then glue into place. I did this by winding fishing line around a piece of cardboard and then tying into three equal bundles. I then used glue to fasten them into the tubes. A note on printing: My prints came out pretty rough and for some reason the middle hole did not print. I had to carve out with a small knife. I will continue to refine and see if I can figure out why!

description.text:
With this you can make a removable buildplate with no clamps on the top of the plate.  
It is easier to take off a part there wont easily leave the build surface when the buildplate is flexible.

It is best for PLA printing with no heated build plate because of the heat contact to clamp. Print it in ABS if possible.

author: jbutj

title: 80mm Fan Mount for Cupcake X-Axis Stepper

description.text:
My cupcake makerbot's x-axis stepper recently started skipping steps, causing majorly mis-aligned (tower of pisa style) builds - after checking nothing was getting in its way, fiddling for hours with the trimpot on the stepper controller, and oiling the guide rods it seemed the stepper was just plain overheating (Sydney's recent 40+ degree celcius weather probably wasn't helping).
Adding a fan to cool the x-axis stepper instantly solved the problem for me - so I made this mount to clip into the cupcake's side port, to hold the fan in place.
Alibre 2011 Source files are included

PARTS
You'll need a garden-variety 80mm computer fan,
4x M3x15mm Bolts
4x M3 Nuts Instructions
Print out fanprint.stl Check the direction of the fan's airflow Bolt the mounts onto the fan in the obvious places Carefully push the mounts into the side port on the cupcake until they snap in, it helps to squeeze the holding tabs together a bit - the hole in the side wall of the mounts is there to allow this :) Power up the fan.

This is a ramp, designed with the intent of making a "water hazard" for a sphero obstacle course. Put one ramp over the end of a water filled tub, and sphero should be able to make it in and out of the water. I was thinking of a "plastic shoe box" type container when I designed the ramp.  I have oriented it for easier printing, but it is meant to have the short side dipping into the water, and the end of the long side taped to the floor.  
I cannot test this yet, and it will take a pretty large printer to do this in one piece, so you'll probably have to break it up and glue the pieces together.   
I am also unsure about the buoyancy of the printed part, higher infills may reduce that if it is problematic, or just use some tape to secure it.

title: Universal Phone and Tablet Stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Lightweight simple universal phone and tablet stand. NB: Print in mm for correct size.
NB: Only version 2 is designed to support larger devices such as tablets. Supports most devices less than 14mm thick (including the devices cover). Version 1 - Universal_Phone_Stand.stl
Version 2 - Universal_Phone_and_Tablet_Stand.stl Update notes:
Version 2 has a stiffer and longer back to support larger devices such as tablets. I also found that I could reduce the height of the front grips without decreasing the reliability. This gives more visible device real estate and easier access to device buttons. Tested Phones:
LG G2, LG G3, LG G6, HTC One M8, Samsung Galaxy Note 2, Samsung Galaxy Note 3, Samsung Galaxy Note 4, Samsung Galaxy Note 5, Samsung Galaxy S3 mini, Samsung Galaxy S5 mini, Samsung Galaxy S3, Samsung Galaxy S4, Samsung Galaxy S5, Samsung Galaxy S6, Apple iPhone 4S, Apple iPhone 5, Apple iPhone 5s, Apple iPhone 6, Apple iPhone 6s, Apple iPhone 7, Hisense Infinity H3 U988, BlackBerry Bold 9790, Sony Xperia E1, Huawei Ascend G7, Huawei Nexus 6P, Huawei P9 and the Nokia Lumia 520. Tested Tablets:
Samsung Galaxy Note 10.1 (2014 Edition), Samsung P1000 Galaxy Tab, Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 10.1, Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 10.1, Mecer A890A Windows Tablet, Apple iPad mini 2 and ASUS ZenPad 10. Let me know if it supports your phone or tablet and I'll add it to the tested list - thanks. Enjoy

We run a small startup called Kiranamix, subscribe to our mailing list to find out what we make next!
http://eepurl.com/bZZtZP

comments.text: I printed out the phone/ tablet stand and it came out really clean and I like it. It's small though (Not always a bad thing) though you may want to let people know its approximate size in the description so they can scale it if they would like.The base may be around two inches wide by three inches long. There is a small ridge between the two uprights that could probably be omitted it's thin and has no actual function. Just a waste of filament. It does do a good job though. I'll probably use this one for phones and scale one a bit wider for my IPad. To those who print this out and are worried about scratches felt with an adhesive backing is a great thing. I use it for a few prints that I don't want to cause scratches. Also little rubber adhesive pads on the bottom, not a bad idea either. I'd like to see a version of this that you could have a charger cord attached to so you could use this as a docking station. It definitely does the job I intended it for.

comments.author: bh56

comments.text: Thanks, I’m glad you like it. I’ve never had a problem printing either version, but my Up Plus 2 deals very well with supports and overhangs. I generally print them lying on their sides (if I’m understanding correctly, that’s what you’re doing) as I find it gives me the best quality for this design. I have however seen a couple people in the “Makes” section that have printed the stand upright and it looks good, so if your printer is struggling with the overhang, maybe give that a try. I generally print with my z resolution at 0.20mm and my quality on normal (these settings often give better results than a z resolution of 0.15mm and quality on fine – but your printer may be different). With regard to temperature, the Up Plus 2 manages the temperature automatically so I wouldn’t know the best temperature (but of course make sure your temperature is appropriate for the material you’re using – the material manufacture normally makes good temperature suggestions). With regard to the materials, I believe your printer can use both ABS and PLA, so as long as you have the right temperature and speed settings either should work. I mostly use ABS, but I want to start using PLA, however I need to tweak my printer a little before I can use PLA consistently (my extruder gear gets a bit too hot for PLA). Hopefully this helps and you come right.
comments.author: bh56

comments.text: Thanks for getting back to me and suggestions.  As you can tell I'm new to 3D printing.  I'm printing in PLA, but maybe should try ABS as well.  I am printing it on it's side as it the design comes.  I'm not sure how to turn on it's other side  The print software that comes to the M3D is pretty basic with not any documentation.   There are 2 options related to support.  The Use support material is checked.  There is a Use model on model support.  This is unchecked.  Not sure what this does.  Maybe I will play around with this setting.  Will let you know how it goes.  Related to temperature the M3D,pretty much handles this as well.
comments.author: jamesdeklerk

comments.text: Any time. Oh and I doubt turning off the Use support material will help if you print it on its side because the overhang is too great (I think it would make it worse, so in general I would keep it on). If you print it upright, it shouldn’t make a difference having it off or on (because then it shouldn’t need support as there are no overhangs greater than 45deg when printing upright). With regard to rotating the model, your printers software should be able to do it, just mess around a bit, but sometimes I use 3D Builder for Windows (here http://apps.microsoft.com/windows/en-za/app/3d-builder/75f3f766-13b3-45e9-a62f-29590d5781f2 if you have Windows 8 or above). I find it easy to use for simple stl editing once you get the hang of it, just play around with it for a couple minutes.

This is a self supporting 1 piece plastic part that requires no assembly. The adapter allows you to use your iPhone 6 to capture still images, video, or FaceTime content from under the microscope. Zoom and focus are provided by the microscope. The adapter is capable of adjusting to eye pieces that vary 30mm +/- 2mm. This part was originally designed in ABS. PLA will likely seem a lot stiffer where the eye piece flexes. Enjoy! -Greg

This file was tested on a Makerbot Replicator 2X. Settings: make a raft, 300 micron layer setting, build plate heated to 110C, Support turned off, grown vertically rested on its flat base, density is 5%. Build time is about an hour and a half  
My extruder tends to print over sized so the undercuts I have to support the bottom of the phone are over-sized to compensate for the part coming in about 0.3mm undersized. When print is finished just peel off the raft and your done!  
Good Luck!

description.text:
Printed motor mount for the mini skywalker plane from hobbyking.
Attaches to the main fuselage and allows the wing to fit inside the models original box for storage. 12mm ,16mm and 16.5mm (for AXN motor) spacing options. Bolts can either be from the back or from the front with nuts in the press-fit hex cavities. Fits 2-56 nuts maybe M-2 New and improved to better accommodate 6" props and I added a 16.5mm version for the AXN motor

Goes between the two fuselage halves. Some foam will have to be removed but it should still be fairly simple to slice out and add this to an already completed model.  
30%- 40% infill should be adequate.  Might need some support for the arched overhang part  
**Note - before gluing,  make sure the the motor angle lines up w/ the mount area on the wing.  On mine, I had to tilt the motor  'up' slightly to achieve the correct position- the the top edge of the fuselage part of the motor mount is flush aft but drops about 1mm below the foam at the fore corner.   Yours may be a little different.

description.text:
Front axle carries for 1:10 scale traxxas 2wd vehicles. You will need 11mm x 4mm bearings/bushings(stock on stampede). Should be direct replacement with a little work.  
Designed this from scratch, old one broke and had no replacement parts available.
If printing with ABS, scale up to 102/103%. I printed with 100% infill. Supports and raft suggested but optional.

comments.text: thank you i designed some but they didnt turn out well and i couldnt fine the fusion file save me the aggravation of making it again will update it once i print it i could have check thingiverse first
comments.author: mason_murray

comments.text:
Had to print at 102% with PLA, seems to fit alright, will test it out tomorrow, thanks for modeling this Reziox!
EDIT: Tested it out some today, ended up breaking both that I had printed, they seem to be about as strong as the OEM ones. (Busted them both by first running into a telephone pole, then a tree)

comments.text: They would probably last longer if your rotated it 90 degreees so it was on the side, mainly because the layer directin change would increase the strength.

comments.text: I have driven three times with these and no sign of any problems. I still would be cautious of crashing a lot, they most likely are not as strong as original parts even though they are thicker. They should do the job for a while unless bash your truck really hard.

title: Polaroid Cube mount for Lego Duplo

description.text: Very simple thing to mount Polaroid Cube to Lego Duplo. The shape is Duplo 2x2x1 brick without studs. It can hold any small coin (for example 5 euro cents) and use Polaroid's built in magnetic holder. Sample video is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oCIPXnPU638
Print, glue a coin to the top and use.
